awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Improving Understanding of River Flood Dynamics by Relating Flow and Sediment Movement to Shapes of River Dunes in three dimensions
awd_abstract_narration:
Much of the world’s population and commerce exist along river corridors. The sustainability of human settlements and the impacts they have on their environments are inextricably tied to river flood and sediment dynamics. Bedforms, migrating mounds of sand such as ripples and dunes, are a primary feature observed on the bottom of dynamic river systems. Their geometries and motions are closely tied to river flow and sediment transport and each one influences the other in complex feedback loops. Direct measurement of all components of these coupled feedbacks is challenging in modern rivers and difficult to interpret in their ancient sedimentary deposits, hindering complete, understanding over long timescales. Over a century of study has attempted to relate bedform shapes, motions, and ancient deposits to the flow and sediment transport conditions that form them. Much of this effort has focused on two-dimensional frameworks. This project establishes a new set of experimental and field techniques in a collaborative setting for collecting coupled measurements of flow, sediment transport, and bedform evolution in three dimensions. In so doing, this work will expand the physical and intellectual capacity of the University of New Orleans to address problems in sediment transport research that extend beyond the scope of this project. This expanded capacity will broaden participation and serve the diverse university community as well as the southeastern region by establishing a highly capable sediment transport facility with state-of-the-art methods at a highly diverse public university in New Orleans. 

Bedforms are a primary observable feature of sediment transport systems. Their geometries and kinematics (motions) are closely coupled to the dynamics (forces) of flow and sediment transport. As such, bedforms and their stratal elements are key to understanding river conditions, past and present. Flow and sediment transport conditions in sand-bed alluvial systems are tightly coupled to the kinematics of bedforms. Bedforms serve to transport bed material sediment, and their forms extract momentum from the flow in alluvial river systems. Understanding their geometry and behavior can inform models that evaluate bed material flux and shear stress partitioning in modern river systems, as well as enhance interpretation of ancient fluvial strata. This project seeks to build capacity, establish lab protocols, and collect data to address three independent hypotheses: First, that cross-stream, relative to downstream, bedload particle excursion length and velocity increase with increasing turbulent energetics of the flow; second, that increasing probabilities of cross-stream particle collisions enable the establishment of three-dimensionality of bedform topography; and third, that turbulent characteristics of flow, namely shear velocity, can be inverted from three-dimensionality of bedforms and the curvature of cross set bounding surfaces in stratigraphy. A complete assessment of these hypotheses will enhance the ability to forward model bedform geometries and kinematics based on flow and sediment transport conditions. This will bolster inverse models used to quantitatively interpret past sediment transport and flow conditions based on observations of stratigraphy. In collaboration with researchers at the University of California, Santa Barbara, this fellowship will address both regionally and nationally relevant problems of river flood dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award focused on building intellectual infrastructure at the University of New Orleans in the field of sediment transport. The scientific goals of the proposal were to investigate and work towards broader collaborative understanding of the three-dimensional evolution of dunes in sand bedded rivers. The three primary outcomes of the proposal were as follows:

Outcome 1 – Capacity at UNO: The proposal period saw tremendous growth in the physical and intellectual capacity at UNO to produce high-resolution repeat topographic measurements in a laboratory river channel. The PI also gained tremendous new knowledge, skills, and experience working with colleagues at UC Santa Barbara as we co-developed our laboratory methods. From this, the PI, the UCSB faculty mentor, and the project Postdoctoral Researcher have each been able to take lead on three specific, unique scientific questions relating to bedform morphodynamics, which are currently in review, accepted, and in preparation for submission to top tier journals in our field, resepctively. 

From the standpoint of the Broader Impacts of the proposal, this outcome has had and will continue to have a major effect on the ability of UNO to train students in an experiential framework. Five undergraduate researchers, including one enrolled at a local community college, have been engaged in research in this flume lab facility, all of whom were non-traditional or first-generation students from backgrounds historically underrepresented in STEM fields.

Outcome 2 – Methods and protocols: Through the course of this proposal and two summer site visits, the PI, the host at UCSB, and the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers involved at both institutions worked closely to develop methods that were comparable across the two laboratories. We leveraged the similarities as well as the differences between the two facilities to allow us to target specific scientific questions that were better addressed in one or the other of the two facilities based upon the methodological advantages in each. The methods from each laboratory have been carefully described in both submitted and accepted publications which are at the time of this report in the process of being made public.

From the standpoint of the Broader Impacts of the proposal, this outcome will enable the UNO sediment transport and hydraulics facility to have an outsized impact in the field, with several publications in progress. Solidification of experimental protocols in this collaborative, cross-laboratory setting has allowed us to design and test our system to get the best possible levels of data reproducibility and fidelity.

Outcome 3 – Collaborative network and collaborative full proposal: The time spent at the host institution was incredibly closely collaborative and resulted in a tremendous amount of connection-making between the two lab groups. We have given several conference presentations with rotating author lists including the PIs, Postdoctoral researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students from both labs. New ideas were able to be originated and discussed, experiments designed and run, and publications prepared all stemming from this close-proximity collaborative setting. We are currently working on a full proposal to be submitted to NSF stemming from new ideas developed during the fellowship period. 

From the standpoint of the Broader Impacts of the proposal, this outcome has resulted in expanded opportunities for student mentees at both institutions. Specifically at UNO, the undergraduates who were able to participate on this project have had the opportunity to be involved data generation and analysis, participate in presentations and publications, and have been able to use these research experiences to jumpstart their research careers. Two of these undergraduate students are now in graduate programs, on is employed in a state scientific agency, and two have yet to graduate.
